Noah Campbell wrote:
>
> Why not teach REST from a systems engineering perspective.  The
> properties that define a RESTful architecture are leveraged by tools
> like HAProxy, Nginx, Squid, Varnish and various other
> intermediaries.  Once you have a good working grasp on how caching,
> etags, HTTP methods and response codes impact the entire system, then
> you can focus on building an app.  Being able to produce a service
> that fits into ecosystem becomes much more relevant then trying to
> drag someone to the conclusion without a tangible example.
> 
> Just a thought.
> 

This may well be a solution for describing to someone what REST *is*.
My hypothesis is that "REST" APIs fail to be RESTful due to a failure
in mapping between architectural model, and implementation.  I'm
concerned with those who already think they know they want REST, but
need help developing a system.  My proposed solution is to teach them
how to develop an architectural model, and help them map that model to
their implementation.  I do not believe that REST can be taught, as it
is an architectural style, by describing implementations.

-Eric
